page.title: 06LILFORD HALL
page.content: { The Hall is set in 240 acres of rolling grassland and woodland and is a listed Jacobean building of great historical and architectural interest. It was built in 1635 and a further wing added 21 years later. The stables and coach house, which now contain the gift shop and craft workshop, were probably built in 1711 and it was also at that time that the spectacular row of 13 chimneys was added. Between 1830 and 1858, the east and west wings were extended, so that the deep U-shaped appearance was formed. It was originally built for one William Elmes, but it passed into the hands of Thomas Powys (whose great-grandson was created the first Lord Lilford in 1797) in 1711. With a short break in recent years, it has remained in Lilford hands ever since.
